Everything had a unique twist that made it a one of a kind experience. The waiter was very attentive and had excellent recommendations. 

The restaurant is set up very nice so that even though it is large with lots of seating, you feel like you are in a small private area. 

My one complaint was with the limp lettuce leaf garnish. It was a pain to separate the fatty falling apart (as it should be) Toro sashimi from the leaf with chop sticks.

The sashimi was pretty good. The rolls were not. They looked really pretty as far as presentation goes, but they were lacking in flavor. It was bland, and I couldn't really distinguish one roll from the next. Tempura was not bad, batter not too greasy. Service was slow, the waiter hardly checked on us. I'm not sure if that was because we sat at the end of the sushi bar. This place is too expensive for what you get. The only thing outstanding was the interior design. It's dark and hip.

What a great place for sushi. Came with a group of 10 and they were extremely accommodating and took great care of our group. Very trendy sushi bar, probably the best one in the hotels if you ask me. Exceptional sake list, and the quality of sushi totally superb. :] I brought my leftovers (Salmon skin hand roll, Kappa Maki, and some edamame) Great drunk food. Great sober food. Good sushi.

Excellent and a bit over priced, this sushi is well worth it!!! But what the heck - you're in Vegas! Shibuya is a elegant place to dine and is artfully decorated and the sushi is plated to match. The tuna sashimi with garlic is to die for! As far as I can tell all the other sushi rolls are wonderful. The sake menu is great, too and the waiters are ready to make suggestions. Let's just say that this place made my husband (an "i'm not gonna eat no fish that isn't cooked" kind of guy) into a sashimi lover. Now he says, "oh, can we get that yummy pink fish that we ate in vegas, again?"
You gotta try this place - at least once.  And I'll be back again. Enjoy!

I loved the food here especially the seared ahi tuna and the toro. The toro was so soft, which led me to believe that they probably ran it through a blender or something because it didn't even feel like I was eating food, almost like it was regurgitated food but in a good way.

The food here is delicious but super expensive. Portion wise they tend to favor presentation over anything else so don't be surprised if you stop by Fat Burger after wards, I know I did.

Their sake selection was pretty good and the staff was pretty knowledgeable about menu items. Overall I had a pretty enjoyable time there and would recommend it.

A sushi knockout! Incredibly fresh fish, interesting cocktails, and flavorful appetizers. I ordered the Miso-glazed Shishito peppers as an appetizer, and I would go back again and again for those alone. I apparently got the last order, because I recommended them to the guy sitting next to me & when he ordered they told him they were out. Lucky me! Next up was the mushroom miso soup (delicious!) then the chef's choice sushi platter (I wanted more!!).  Cocktails were overpriced, but that's par for the course in Vegas. Ambience is great - beautiful space.

pedimos dos colas de langostas  una para cada uno,el restaorante es de 1ra calidad ,el servicio se me hizo espectacular todo el mundo sabe su trabajo,te tratan como si fueras el unico huesped y consumidor del mundo,son muy sociables,la langosta estaba exquisita ,pedi un jugo de naranja y tube que pedir otro ,el servicio fue como si estubieras en europa,en un sitio de gente importante,fueron sonriendo y solo de levantar tu mirada ellos estan pensando que tu necesitas algo,fueron 4 ocaciones para ver que no faltara nada en la mesa,el costo es yo diria que caro dos personas 110 dollares,pero para lo que hechas en las maquinas no se hace caro ,yo regresare claro que si ,donde me traten bien ahi estare.

I went on the recommendation from several colleagues that this is the BEST sushi in Las Vegas.  While that is a steep bill, I found everything truly delicious!!  The appetizers are incredible and not to be missed.  Also the wine was reasonably priced (surprising for Vegas).  Great service, fun ambience.  YUM

Me and my girlfriend love sushi, so we went to Shibuya yesterday. We ordered the full set menu and a bottle of wine. The service was great.

As for the food, both presentation and taste was good, but no "wow" effect. Also, the rice for the nigri was overcooked and seemed like it was not fresh. 

Ambience was nice and overall a good experience - however, not great

One of my two favorite restaurants in Vegas so far!

EVERYTHING on the menu is delicious!

Lychee martinis and edamame to start... then the AUSTRALIAN KOBE BEEF TATAKI... heavenly!!! It melts in your mouth!

KHO HAKU & CRISPY SPICY TUNA rolls were two of the best rolls I've had in a while!!  Then CREME BRULEE DUO for dessert!! The perfect amount and combination of flavors overall!

I've eaten alot of sushi in Sao Paulo Brasil, some of the best in the world, but Shibuya is up toward the top of the list for me now!  The overall ambience of the restaurant makes it even that much better!

This is also a GREAT DATE RESTAURANT because of the separation of tables with dark brown bamboo sticks, making it very private yet you can still see everything going on around you.

Shibuya is a Japanese fine dining restaurant located in MGM.

They have several different dining options.  You can choose the regular dining experience, sushi bar, or teppanyaki.  The first two probably speak for themselves but not everyone may know what teppanyaki is.  The way the staff at Shibuya explained it to me was that it was similar to the dining experience at Benihana.  Make sense? Ok, great.  

We chose the regular dining experience.  Shibuya is dimly lit with an intricate interior design that is very unique.  It is somewhat similar to a dining experience in Japan where you are separated by shoji, paper like walls, except here they are vine like cut pieces of wood that run from the floor to the ceiling.  This creates an intimate experience for each dining party.  Tables and seating are very different as well.  Your seat is one long bench.  For a party of two you each get your own bench that are larger than chairs but are only meant for one.  

The service was outstanding here.  They were attentive and filled drinks for you as you ran low.  

I had the hamachi kama which was broiled yellowtail that was complete with all of the bones still intact.  This could be difficult to eat for a chopstick novice but I was able to manage.  They did offer fork and knife in case I needed to use them.  This dish was good and the experience here was nice.

* I used my open table dining check here without any issues

This is some of the freshest & most delicious sushi I have ever had, and I have consumed a lot of sushi in my lifetime. The salmon nigiri was soft like butter & after consulting with the server confirmed that it was scottish which I wasn't surprised by considering the color & flavor of the fish. We also ordered pepperfin which was melt in your mouth amazing along with the shibuya roll and edamame for appetizers. In terms of atmosphere & service this place also takes the cake as well. We went in with a big party of 15 and were seated right away. We had dinner here on a night when there was a big boxing match at the MGM but it was about to start so perhaps that's why they weren't too busy. Anyway, all of our food was out in a timely manner & the server was very attentive. The place also feels very vogue with the low lighting, vaulted ceilings and long sleek tables. For dress code I would say business casual definitely works although more to the business end of that definition.  All in all this place was awesome & definitely somewhere I need to stop in to on all future trips to Vegas.

I've been here twice -- once with a big group and once with my boyfriend.  I thought the food was good, but I wasn't really impressed. Also, I live in the Bay Area where it's easy to find really great, inexpensive sushi, so it's hard for me to be impressed by the sushi. I have to say that the braised kobe ribs were good though, and the service was awesome!

We should have gone else where. I was telling myself the entire time before setting up the reservation "Why would you ever go to a sushi joint or restaurant that is so far inland and so far away from the ocean?". I should have stuck to my first though and gone anywhere else.

We decided to get the Futari Omakase which runs $80 per person. This is the run down on the food:
1) Cucumber Sunomono (AMUSE) - ya... the Japanese cucumbers covered in MSG is actually a dish and not just given to you like you would get artisan bread at an Italian place.
2) Yellowtail Sashimi and a King, Snow and Dungeness Crab Salad - The sashimi was about average. It is comparable to something you can get at your average sushi joint around your home. They butchered the yellowtail. The salad was average.
3) Shibaki Tuna Tartare and the Toban Spiced Albacore- On the albacore they put these... what I can only describe and probably is French's Onion all over the albacore. Although it was decent... there is probably a sushi chef rolling around in his grave. The tartare was bleh.
4) Lobster and Scallop - this was actually very good and was probably the highlight of the meal
5) Miso Soup - the Miso Soup was so awkwardly placed in the meal that I was actually getting sick from it. At this point in the meal we had gone through a couple of bottles of cold sake. Then they introduced this hot miso soup... it did not sit well with me the hot and cold liquid. Ewwwww. I felt like sh*t after this. Normally miso soup is one of, if not, the first things you get and not the last courses in the meal. Someone forgot to tell them that.
6) Nigiri - Average.... same this as the sashimi. average at best.
7) Dessert Trio (Yuzu Momo Parfait, Choco-Lychee Mousse, Mochi Ice Cream) - by this time I was feeling sick from the cold sake and the hot miso soup. I tried each of the desserts, but didn't care for them. I just needed to sit for a bit.

Overall, this was a horrible experience. We easily dropped a few Benjamins on the meal and sake only to feel kind of sick after all was said and done. I wish I had gone anywhere else that night. No single dish was bad (most were average or better), but it just goes to show you that the intangible things like course order can totally screw up the experience.

Came here for dinner before some bachelorette festivities and this place was awesome! We originally had a reservation for 730 bit called to move it to 7 and it was no problem for them. 

Our waiter was attentive and made sure our drinks were full and our table was clean at all times. The atmosphere is trendy and you definitely feel like you're in Vegas. Now for the best part... The food. I ordered the shishito peppers to start which were a huge hit with the whole table. Then I got the crispy rice and tuna... This was to die for. You get these individual squares I'd fried rice and spicy tuna to pair it with... AMAZING. Then I also got the shibuya roll which has soft shell crab inside and hamachi on top, delicious.

Everybody I was with was happy with their food and we all cleaned our plates as best we could. If you love Japanese food and are in Vegas this is a MUST visit.
Pictures are worth a thousand words!!! I had the A5 Japanese Wagyu! Totally worth 300 buck!! Ask for chef David!!

One of the best meal in Vegas!! The ambiance, foods, and service are at best. They have awesome selections of Sake, from $20-$800. Yes, you got it, $800! Also, they have lobster by pounds, 3lbs. is like $700.
If you want to have a romantic, but hip dinner, you should definitely try this place, worth your $$$$

AS BEST AS YOU CAN GET.

It's really not for people who don't enjoy sushi-type of food. While they do have warm plates, Shibuya of course specializes in raw fish. Which isn't a bad thing! My family definitely enjoyed themselves and particularly awestruck by their interior design (being designers themselves, go figure lol).

FOOD:
We ordered two Miso Soups ($6.00 for original and add Mushroom +$1.00). Then ordered an array of of nigiri and sushi rolls: Yellowtail, Unagi, Tuna, Scallop, and Oh Toro ($8.00-$13.00 per order); Rolls: Spicy tuna ($12.00) and Dragon Roll ($19.00). Also ordered two warm plates: Spring Chicken Moromi Miso and a Black Cod Miso. Cannot say how the sushi were as I do not enjoy fish as much as my family does, but their Spring Chicken Moromi Miso was quite delicious. Very soft in nature, cooked in a method that gave it a very tender texture and the marinade of moromi miso was delectable!

SERVICE:
Everything at Vegas at these upscale restaurants are always up to par and always so delicately done. Everyone is so friendly and just very accommodating to every customers needs. The hostess was super gracious since we got there 30 minutes early and needed to wait outside for the restaurant to open. She made sure we were one of the first families to get in. Our waitress was very knowledgeable whenever we had questions about the dishes and the water waiter always made sure to keep our water filled.

AMBIANCE:
It's a very chic vibe you walk in, the design aspect was beautiful. I loved their bar area with gradual changing LED lights with these clear box layer on top. Ugh! It's just gorgeous. The way it was done wasn't tacky like most places. The noise level here was also minimal with a rule of no rowdy kids under the age of 5 allowed. I loved it.

Definitely a place I would suggest to sushi lovers. :)
Great nigiri but not so great rolls. I would have given 5 stars if I had just nigiri. Try the tuna. Best tuna i've ever had

We were staying at the MGM Signature and popped in to Shibuya for dinner.  The service was extremely attentive (but not overbearingly so) though there was a mixup with the sake.  We ordered a bottle of sake.  We were presented with a carafe of the right kind, but warmed up (ick).  They left us a glass and corrected the problem promptly.  

The food was also solid.  I thought the value was fairly good.  Portions were reasonable, and for the warm dishes quite large.  Quality was generally very good, though the anago could have been better.

So, we had:
SEAWEED TASTING - Seasoned Chuka, Mixed Tosaka, Cooked Sweet Hijiki, Citrus Red Shibazuke
SALMON AND BLACK COD - Pineapple Miso Salmon, Shiro Miso Black Cod
SEARED AKAMI TUNA - Kizami Wasabi Apple Cider Soy Reduction, Vegetable Roll
Kanpachi :: Young Yellow Tail
Uni :: Sea Urchin
Anago :: Sea Eel
HANNYA ROLL - Crispy Soft Shell Crab, Jalapeño, Topped With Spicy Albacore, Ponzu

The standouts were the salmon and black cod, the uni, and the little mountain peach things that came along with the wasabi and ginger.  They were new to us, and a nice treat.

We ordered the $120pp omakase, each dish was so delicious and unique, except for the last sushi dish which was just average.  I think it worth the price for the quality of food you get, the toro and the foie gras were heavenly!  A big variety selection of sake, most of them cannot be purchased from the supermarket.  The sake is expensive, but I guess that's the average price for a restaurant like this located inside the casino.  Service was good, overall experience was good, just a bit too pricy.

This is one of the best Japanese restaurant on the strip!

Restaurant decor is very nice and comtemporary.  We ordered quite a lot of food that night:

Two sushi rolls (dragon roll and forgot the name of the other, both average)

Sashimi (Toro & smoked salmon, both good but not great, i had better elsewhere)

Teppanyaki (Seafood combo, wagyu striploin, angus tenderloin)

A bottle of sake

Among all the food, tepanyaki is the BEST, well seasoned and tasted excellent. The chef was very friendly and knowledgeable, not much a show (he even said we were there to eat, not to watch a show or we should buy show ticket elsewhere, well honestly it is true and usually only confident chef can have this kind of attitude!) 

However service was very disappointing, we had to ask for everything from start to the end.  Our wait staff seems not expecting/wanting us to order more food: He kept the non-teppanyaki menu from us all the time or hurry to get menu back after we ordered a few thing.  We had to check with him about our food, and he was hurry to take away our plates (didn't they want us to order more?)

The tab wasn't too bad but i will come back for teppanyaki only.  Hopefully the service will be improved next time.

Again, im not a sushi lover but i would have to say this place is amazing.

Aside from its trendy atmosphere and excellent service, I really liked their warm plates. I recommend...

KUROBUTA PORK CRISP
4 Hour Braised Black Pork Seared Tofu, Nihon Glaze

JAPANESE WAGYU STRIPLOIN
4 oz A4 , Black Truffle Ponzu, Roasted Shimeji and Maitake Mushrooms

SALMON AND BLACK COD
Pineapple Miso Salmon, Shiro Miso Black Cod

all of these dishes really satisfied my food fantasies. The crunchy shell made the pork very delightful to eat and the tofu on top made the display really pretty. And again being the well done meat eater that i am the wagyu beef was cooked perfectly and served deliciously with the maitake mushrooms and a light soy sauce...

For what you pay for, i really couldnt ask for more. Its a bit pricey but well worth the fresh fish and delicious warm plates...

Very pricey, but good food. I also appreciate that the teppanyaki is served with the meat course first, rather than filling you up on rice and veggies.

I enjoyed the sashimi I had, especially the kanpachi. 

The chef was there to cook and not flip knives, just FYI.

Service was okay; there seemed to be a few miscommunications at our table.

A reservation for 5:30 when they opened was just enough time for us to finish up before the curtain for the first Ka performance of the evening.

I love Shibuya!  Definitely one of my favorite places for Japanese food in Vegas!  The staff is really great and checks up on you quite frequently.  I always get the Black Angus Tenderloin- really tender meat and not too expensive!  Their tempura is also delicious.  

Definitely make reservations because it can get pretty crowded- especially if there's a MMA fight going on during the weekend.

This place is freakin' AWESOME! In short, very upscale, sexy atmosphere, and wonderful service. It's so relaxed and sophisticated, I forgot I was in a casino hotel.

Mind you, we didn't have reservations, but the wait was only about 15 minutes. On a SATURDAY night!

I didn't think I'd be able to eat much (I'm vegan), but I mentioned it to the waiter and he was super accommodating. Shibuya has a fairly simple-looking menu, seperated into hot dishes, cold dishes, and rolls. He knew off-hand what had what ingredients in it, and had the chef modify a dish for me. I ate the mushroom salad (5 or 6 different sauteed mushrooms in a savory sauce) and some sea salt edamame. Simple as the meal was, presentation was gorgeous, and the mushrooms were really filling for what the portion looked like. They have THE most extensive sake list I've ever seen/heard of, and the waiter even explained the different processes/types of rice grain/food pairings of whatever we asked about.

Great experience, I'd go back again. And eat the same exact thing, with a smile on my face.

They do what they do well, the basics that have been around for over 8 years. Service is exceptional as it should be at a top tier Vegas restaurant. 

Miso black cod, great choice, but I have literally seen this same dish on over 20 different restaurants menus so I'm expecting a consistent product whether I dined at Nobu, or in this case, Shibuya. 

I had a seaweed sampler, which was great. And their shishito peppers were large, and also in a miso glaze, charred to perfection. 

Now why 3/5 ?

I ordered Salmon sushi.
Ate the first piece right away, fish was excellent. 
The rice? Here was my thought process:
"Great fish, wait -- is this rice actually hard?"
Second piece of the order - even harder rice. 
I kind of wanted to cancel my meal at that point but my cod was about to arrive. 

I haven't EVER experienced hard sushi rice at any Asian restaurant let alone a $$$$ rating spot like Shibuya. 
I told the waiter, he mentioned to manager. Manager apologized. 

They forgot to take it off the bill, so I had to remind them (and they would have definitely forgotten had I not caught it)

I cannot recommend this restaurant without disclaimers regarding having hard sushi rice. 

It's absolutely unacceptable in my opinion and the Chef should have known the quality of the rice was not up to even the most lenient of standards. 

A shame, because I was looking forward to coming back again to try their rolls, but after my rice experience here, I probably won't return despite everything else tasting great.

Grew up on Maui and lived in Newport beach and San Diego for years. This is the best sushi I've ever had, they crush Nobu to bits. I had blue fin sashimi special that brought me back to my childhood instantly. Freshest and best oyster ever! The lobster roll is a tempura lobster tail, and has the best biggest mouthful of lobster bites you could ever hope for. Just eat here, it's so worth $100 per person It's not even funny. Oh, the service and decor are also top notch, making it worthy of five stars easy!!

Because the hubs enjoys sashimi we had to visit this visually appealing restaurant.  Quite trendy and inviting. 

The selection of sashimi was extensive and his mouth was apparently having a party hehe.  His fave is hamachi but he ordered many other varieties.  

Because I'm still trying sashimi, I ordered from their 'warm plates'.  The jidori chicken was surprisingly tasty.  I have had my share of sushi restaurant cooked entrees and you really go to these places for the sushi/sashimi so I don't expect much.  This entree was made with love and sympathy for those who enjoy cooked goodies.  

So the hubs and I both enjoyed this dining experience.  He was happy for me since he can tell that I was elated with my entree decision.

For the dessert, I chose the berries warabi which was an assortment of mixed berries, ginger creme, green tea-dusted warabi, and soy milk gelato.  Hubs enjoyed the choco lychee that was a chocolate mousse cake, w/lychee vanilla jelly and chocolate soy milk ice cream.

This place is overall a delight for both sushi/sashimi and/or warm entrees. 

It's a casual environment but the dress code description on MGM's link reads as 'business casual'.  We must have had the acceptable attire because the dress code was the last thing in our vacationing minds.  

Reservations are highly recommended but we dined there before the dinner rush so we just walked in.

If you're an experienced sushi eater, don't go here. Maybe teppanyaki would have been better. 

Cool relaxed vibe. Some casual diners, some dressed up. It's Vegas.

Best thing about my dinner: Blood Orange Mojito. 
- Salmon sashimi with wassabi mayo and pickled vegetables. Fair, quality of salmon not up to par with what I'm used to
- Poached Lobster and Scallop in UMI butter. Lobster not cooked consistently, some overdone some perfect. Scallop also overdone. UMI butter was very rich, if you like that.
- Ise Ibe roll: dry dry and more dry. Poached Maine Lobster, Kimchee Aioli and Asparagus inside Soy Paper topped with Tobiko and Crunchy Tempura. Like the idea of the soy paper, but even after dipping w/soy sauce (I don't like to overdip), I thought I was going to choke from the dryness. 

Staff was nice, but I won't be back.
The best sushi outside of my home town of Seattle! Excellent customer service and great atmosphere. I highly recommend you try this place, especially if you are a sushi lover.

When I called to make a reservation at the Teppanyaki table I was given a hard time by the hostess because two of the four people in my party wanted sushi, while the other two wanted teppanyaki. They require the majority of the party to have teppanyaki but I was not about to separate my party into two tables. I think that is just ridiculous. Our waitor also seemed pissed when I told him that I wanted a sushi menu. 

We were sat with a family with three children who were very misbehaved and the parents did little to aknoledge this behavior. Our server was awkward and forgot my miso soup. However, the server assistants were great. The teppanyaki chef wasn't very animated nor was his performance interesting to watch. 

The sushi was good. I tried to torro scallion roll which was extremely good. I also really liked the Kho Haku specialty roll. Although these were good, it was nothing I couldn't get at the sushi place I frequent at home.

We came in with a business group of 10 people and the service was great and attentive to our needs. The sushi apps were tasty and the main dished were cooked to perfection. I have tasted better but it is a nice place to go to impress.

Every trip to Vegas I tell myself I'm going to splurge a little bit and try the tasting menu at Shibuya and this time I did. All i can say is OMG, so worth it!! 

This was seriously some of the best food I've had in my life. I have a love affair with sushi and my bf and I agreed, this was the best sushi we've had yet. The yellowtail sashimi was so unexpectedly flavorful and extremely fresh. The spicy tuna roll was the most generously apportioned spicy tuna roll I've ever had and also the TASTIEST! The show stealer, however,  was the miso BLACK COD... it was just melt in your mouth good. Me and my bf laugh at people who tell stories about food being orgasmic (use to think they were all just fatties), but we have officially changed our ways after being blessed with that fish. It was so delicate and flavorful we gave it the name buttafish.

Quick run down of the other dishes we tasted:
Miso Salmon- Awesome
Beef Tenderloin with Truflle Ponzu- Awesome
Salmon and Avocado Roll- Awesome
Starter Salad- Rather Subpar
Chilled Soup (can't remember exact name)- Very good but kinda reminded me of birds nest soup from bizarre foods so creeped me out a lil. 

I wanted to give this place five stars so bad but..... the drinks were weak and the dessert was blah. Had the lychee martini and it tasted like straight lychee juice. I def didn't plan to pay $12 for no darn lychee juice! From what I've read in other reviews, this is the norm. Dessert was the trio of mochi ice creams and, while not exactly the same as the trader joes variety, it was definitely far from gourmet. 

So four stars for Shibuya for now until they step up their drink game and offer some better dessert on that tasting menu.  

And oh yea, while we were falling in love with our buttafish, we look up and see Mr. Lebron James walking on by. Oh wait, he's now walking in and having teppenyaki. Should that then take this rating up to a five star??!! Heck no! Go Lakers!!

We had dinner here one evening as a company. They accommodated a group of about 16 with very short notice, and the staff was very quick and attentive. 

I had the peach cocktail which was really good, and a spicy tuna roll, which was one of the best quality I've had. Our table also shared the dessert sampler, of which I really enjoyed the Calpico Pannacotta. We also had a taste of the Tiramisu dessert the other table got, which was interesting, but tasty. Hopefully we go when we come back in two weeks :) I'd like to try some of their signature rolls.

The ambiance was gorgeous, great service, and good food.

Came in here before heading to a show. Running short on time, we told our server we had to get out of there in 30-40 minutes. The chef comes out, cooks, we eat & we get out in 30 minutes to make it to our show. Amazing ! 

We got the wagyu skirt steak and lobster with fried rice and veggies.

It was the most expensive teppenyaki I've ever had, but what do you expect it's Vegas!

I've been here at least 3 times now and every visit leaves me wanting more.

Recently, I visited for an early dinner and opted for the Chef's Tasting. Once you get over the sticker shock, $120 per person, it's a delightful experience. Don't bother asking what's on the menu, just go with it. No thinking- just eating. Of course, if you have a shellfish allergy DO TELL them that so they can make adjustments.

One of my favorite flavor combinations is yuzu and truffle oil. I'm crave this and actually think of Shibuya each time I want to relive this taste experience.

The sake pairing is another $55 per person. However, we chose to go with 2 bottles of 300ml sake instead. These 2 bottles took us through the 8 courses. I started with the Demon Slayer and then moved to the Only Daughter ... or some name like that. The meats and rich flavors paired well with the "Only Daughter." 

If you ever want to treat yourself to some amazing sushi and money is no object, come here. It's sooooo good.

Absolutely loved dining at Shibuya! We are vegetarians and Jeffer was able to completely design an amazing meal for us. All their sauces & tofu are made in house which is incredible. The dining experience and the service was impeccable. I highly recommend Shibuya!

great ambience and service from the get go.
good selectionof fresh sashimi and sushi. jalapeño Hamachi was delicious! Miso black cod, lobster and scallops and there take on fish and chips were all excellent. coffee comes in a French press, which is my favorite! be ready to eat because there is so much to try but beware your pocket book as it can add up fast.
truly a contemporary take on Japanese cuisine and it won't dissapoint. recommend coming in a group to mix and match.

Great atmosphere & decor... went here with eight girls, ready for drinks and fun. The service was good and quick...

Tuna Tartare: looked delicious and got a thumbs up from my girl friends
Miso Cod: YUM
shishito peppers: not my favorite, too spicy and not cooked as much as I like.
shibuya roll: YUM!
the sushi was fresh and tasty...only the albacore was too peppered on the top and it got in the way of the flavor.

All in all, I would go back and I would feast on the black cod, salmon, shibuya roll and a tuna tartare!

The food was superb, the ambiance lovely (we ate early to make it to a show) and the portions were perfect. My only complaint is that with entrees between $35 and $45, it's a bit of an insult to be charged for a portion of white rice. 
My dish of lobster and scallops in buttery sauce was lovely. For my less adventurous husband, the Tempura Chefs Selection, was great. Our dessert of Mochi Ice Cream was just right finish along with green tea.
